people.title: Professor
people.description: Thomas Serre is the Thomas J. Watson, Sr. Professor of Science and Professor of Cognitive & Psychological Sciences and Computer Science at Brown University. He is the Faculty Director of the Center for Computation and Visualization and Associate Director of the Center for Computational Brain Science. He also holds an International Chair in AI within the Artificial and Natural Intelligence Toulouse Institute (ANITI) (France). Dr. Serre received his Ph.D. in Neuroscience from MIT (2006) and MSc in EECS from Télécom Bretagne, France (2000). His research focuses on understanding neural computations supporting visual perception, with particular emphasis on the role of recurrent and feedback processes in visual reasoning. His work bridges neuroscience and artificial intelligence, developing brain-inspired computational models that have been featured in outlets including BBC, The Economist, New Scientist, and Scientific American. Dr. Serre serves as area chair for top-tier conferences including CVPR, ICML, ICLR, and NeurIPS, and as section editor for PLOS Computational Biology. He received an NSF Early Career Award and DARPA Young Faculty Award. His team's work on human action recognition earned the IEEE PAMI Helmholtz Prize (2021) and Mark Everingham Prize (2022). Personal website: https://tserre.github.io/

people.title: Assistant Professor of Research
people.description: Drew Linsley is an Assistant Professor of Research in the CLPS department. He builds computational models of the visual system that serve the dual purpose of (1) explaining biological function and (2) extending artificial vision.

people.title: PhD student
people.description: Alekh Ashok is a PhD student at Brown University working at the intersection of computer vision, neuroscience, and cognitive science. His research focuses on building biologically-inspired artificial vision models, developing training algorithms, and collecting neural data (ECoG). He is particularly interested in recurrent neural network models for vision. Prior to his PhD, he spent two years as a researcher at Brown and worked as a software engineer at Walmart's R&D division. He received his Bachelor of Engineering with a focus on electrical and computer science, where he worked on machine learning-based image compression. Personal website: https://alekhka.github.io/

people.title: PhD student
people.description: Sixuan Chen is a PhD student in Cognitive, Linguistic, and Psychological Sciences. Her current research centers on understanding the mechanisms of mental simulation.

people.title: PhD student
people.description: Yu-Ang is a graduate student in Cognitive Science PhD program at the Department of Cognitive, Linguistic & Psychological Sciences (CLPS). He earned his BS in Psychology from Peking University. Currently, he is focused on building computational models of the vision system to explain the psychophysical, imaging, and neurophysiological findings.

people.title: MSc student
people.description: Akash's research focuses on (i) data-driven AI models that learn generalizable representations, (ii) computer vision models with decisions and objectives grounded in human semantics, and (iii) deploying AI models in real-world environments. www.akashnagaraj.me

people.title: PhD student
people.description: Peisen Zhou is a PhD student in Cognitive, Linguistic, and Psychological Sciences at Brown University. His research interests include computational neuroscience and visual cognition, with a focus on understanding the neural mechanisms underlying visual perception.

people.title: PhD student
people.description: Abdullah Rashed Ahmed is a PhD student at Brown University working on computational models of vision and artificial intelligence. His research explores the intersection of deep learning and cognitive neuroscience to better understand visual information processing.

people.title: PhD student
people.description: Michael Lepori is a Ph.D. student in Computer Science at Brown University. He received his BS in Physics and Computer Science from Johns Hopkins University. He is broadly interested in the intersection of cognitive science and machine learning, and his current research seeks to characterize the kinds of algorithms neural networks implement when solving compositional tasks.

people.title: PhD student
people.description: Julien Colin is a first-year Ph.D. at ELLIS Alicante, co-supervised by Nuria Oliver and Thomas Serre. He received his Master's Degree in Cognitive Sciences: Natural and Artificial Cognition from Grenoble Institute of Technology (France). His research interests include topics related to Computer Vision, Machine Learning, and Computational Cognitive Science. His current research focuses on modeling the interpretability of deep learning models using human-centered approaches.

people.title: MSc student
people.description: Xizheng Yu is a Master's student at Brown University. His research interests include computer vision and machine learning, with a focus on developing computational approaches to understand visual intelligence.

people.title: Researcher at CNRS
people.description: Victor Boutin is a CNRS researcher working at the intersection of computational neuroscience and AI. He holds a Ph.D. from Aix-Marseille University (2020) and an MSc from École Centrale (2011). His research investigates how the visual cortex learns to generalize from limited data. He combines theoretical modeling, machine learning, and cognitive experiments. His current focus is on building biologically inspired models of human-like generalization.

people.title: PhD student
people.description: Bastien Lelan is a PhD student at ANITI with a strong background in computational neuroscience. He recently completed research at Harvard University working with Gabriel Kreiman and Margaret Livingstone, where he focused on understanding neural mechanisms underlying visual processing. His research interests span the intersection of neuroscience, machine learning, and computer vision.

people.title: PhD student
people.description: Jorge Chang is a PhD student at ANITI who will begin his doctoral studies in January 2026. He recently completed his Master of Science degree at Brown University, where he conducted research in the Serre Lab, gaining experience in computational approaches to understanding visual perception and neural mechanisms. His work focuses on bridging neuroscience and artificial intelligence to develop better models of biological vision.

people.title: PostDoc
people.description:
My research blends neural data analysis, cognitive science, and artificial intelligence to understand how the brain guides behavior in complex environments, with a particular interest in behaviors that leverage memory. To develop and test new hypotheses about natural intelligence, I enjoy developing and deconstructing recurrent neural network models that instantiate the underlying neural and cognitive mechanisms, and developing new techniques for analyzing experimental data.
If you are interested in my research, feel free to reach out!
